title: Campagnolo’s Bora and Bora Ultra WTO wheels get wider, lighter and faster
content:
Cyclist
Campagnolo’s Bora and Bora Ultra WTO wheels get wider, lighter and faster

Campagnolo has given its Bora Ultra WTO and Bora WTO wheelsets a refresh to keep up with modern wheel and tyre trends. 

There are three wheel depths on offer for both wheelsets: 35mm, 45mm and 60mm. Campagnolo claims weights per pair from 1,285g for the disc brake-only wheels, a reduction of 100g from the previous generation and only slightly more than the Hyperon Ultra climber’s wheel.

It also says that the new, 23mm wide rim profile is optimised for 28mm tyres and results in up to 80% reduction in drag in a 15° crosswind.

Campagnolo Bora Ultra WTO wheelset retail prices start at £3,290 / $4,090 / €3,690, while Bora WTO wheels are priced from £2,290 / $2,790 / €2,590. 

Related Posts

Attention climbers, Campagnolo’s Hyperon Ultra is back as a 1,240g disc wheelset

Are ceramic bearings worth it?

New rim profile, same clustered spokes

It’s been 30 years since Campagnolo first launched the Bora wheelset and the new Bora Ultra WTO and Bora WTO wheels have the same distinctive G3 clustered spoke pattern with 2:1 spoking in the front and rear wheels as their predecessors. 

This is claimed to result in a very stiff wheel with a more even balance in spoke tension and to increase the efficiency of power transfer. It’s also said to reduce transmission of road vibrations and reduce the wheel weight. 

There’s an internal rim width increase from 19mm to 23mm. Although a few years ago, 19mm would have been progressive it now feels quite retro, with almost all newer rims well into the 20s to support the 28mm-plus tyres typical on modern road and gravel bikes. We marked the previous generation Bora Ultra wheels down on this when we tested them in 2021.

Campagnolo says that the wider rim helps to support wider tyres better, providing a larger contact area which aids ‘trajectory control’ as well as aerodynamics.

Improved aerodynamics 

On the aero front, Campag claims that the new rim profile decreases drag in a headwind by 13% from the previous model Bora wheels and as much as 80% in a 15° crosswind. 

Campagnolo has revamped its carbon layup in the rim to reduce weight, with the carbon fibres arranged around the spoke holes to add extra strength, rather than the latter being punched through the fibres.

The rim bed of the Bora Ultra wheels uses Campagnolo’s Aero Mo-Mag design, with concealed nipples housed in fibreglass-reinforced seats within the rim, which it says improves aerodynamics. The standard Boras have external nipples.

Both the Bora Ultra and Bora have a sealed rim that doesn’t need to be taped and uses the brand’s long-established 2-Way Fit system which pre-dates the widespread adoption of tubeless tyres and allows either tubed or tubeless running. 

Campagnolo says that there’s a 135g drop in rim weight as a result of the HULC (hand-made ultra-light carbon) construction of the Bora Ultra. This lowers resin content, resulting in a headline weight for the 35mm depth wheelset of 1,285g.

While the previous generation Bora wheelsets were available in both rim brake and disc brake format, Campagnolo has continued its march towards a disc brake-only future with the new wheels, mirroring its decision to only offer disc brakes with its latest top tier Super Record Wireless groupset.

Bora Ultra WTO wheels

Campagolo throws all its best wheel tech at the Bora Ultra WTO wheels. 

They use seven spoke clusters and include top spec CULT ceramic bearings in the hubs. The front hub shell is made of carbon fibre rather than alloy. 

The rim is made of Campagnolo’s highest grade HULC carbon, with a smooth, unlacquered finish, which it says helps ensure safe seating of tubeless tyres, as well as saving weight. The spoke nipples are recessed into the rim to improve aerodynamics.

Bora Ultra WTO wheelset claimed weights are 1,285g for the 35mm depth, 1,325g for 45mm and 1,395g for 60mm. Retail prices are from £3,290 / $4,090 / €3,690.

Bora WTO wheels

The (slightly) less flashy and pricy Bora WTO wheels have eight spoke clusters rather than seven and use Campagnolo’s standard USB ceramic bearings in place of CULT. 

They also include external nipples, rather than the Ultra’s hidden nipples and are made of less flashy carbon fibre, although with a similar layup. The finish is lacquered, unlike the Bora Ultra, and the front hub is alloy rather than carbon.

Claimed weights for the Bora WTO wheels are 1,370g for 35mm depth, 1,405g for 45mm and 1,460g for the 60mm. Retail prices are from £2,290 / $2,790 / €2,590.

Read our buyer’s guide to available wheels with a Campagnolo N3W freehub option.

The post Campagnolo’s Bora and Bora Ultra WTO wheels get wider, lighter and faster appeared first on Cyclist.
author: pnorman
